heroDescription: Global Plasma Leader • 29,904 Employees • 1H FY26: US$8.3B Revenue
heroCompanyDescription: CSL Limited (ASX: CSL) is a global biotherapeutics company and the world's largest collector and manufacturer of human plasma-derived therapies. Operating through CSL Behring (plasma), CSL Seqirus (vaccines), and CSL Vifor (iron deficiency), the company serves patients in over 100 countries. Shares at 8-year lows following CEO departure, $1.1B impairments, and 81% reported NPAT drop in 1H FY26 — though underlying NPATA only fell 7% and guidance was reaffirmed.

skew.rationale: 8-year low valuation at 13.4x forward P/E with underlying business intact. 1H was messy (81% reported NPAT drop, $1.1B impairments, CEO exit), but underlying NPATA only fell 7%, guidance reaffirmed, Behring margins expanding, and $550M cost savings on track. The market is pricing the worst-case transformation scenario while ignoring the franchise quality. Risk skew tilts upside at these levels.

verdict.text: 1H FY26 results are in and the picture is clear: this is a messy transition, not a broken franchise. Reported NPAT dropped 81% to US$401M on $1.1B of impairments (mRNA write-down, Venofer generics, plant closures), but underlying NPATA fell only 7% to US$1.9B. CEO McKenzie exited the day before results. The stock crashed 17% to 8-year lows at A$151. At 13.4x forward P/E, the market is pricing permanent impairment of the core plasma franchise — which the numbers do not support. Behring margins are expanding, Vifor grew 12%, and full-year guidance was reaffirmed. The execution risk is real, but the price dislocation now exceeds the fundamental risk.

featuredRationale: 1H FY26: 81% reported NPAT drop on $1.1B impairments, but underlying NPATA only -7%. CEO exited day before results. Stock at 8-year lows, cheapest P/E in 14 years. Franchise intact, transformation messy.

identity.overview: Global biotherapeutics leader headquartered in Melbourne. CSL Behring is the world's largest plasma collector and manufacturer. 1H FY26 revealed a company in messy transition: revenue US$8.3B (-4% CC), underlying NPATA US$1.9B (-7%), but reported NPAT just US$401M (-81%) after US$1.1B in impairments (mRNA write-down $430M, Venofer generics $356M, plant closures $170M). CEO Paul McKenzie departed the day before results. Behring gross margins expanded to 51.7% (target 57% by FY28). Vifor grew 12%. Full-year guidance reaffirmed. Stock crashed 17% to 8-year lows at A$151 before recovering to ~A$163.

hypotheses.title: D1: Structural Compounder Resumes
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↓ 1H missed guidance pace; franchise quality unchanged
hypotheses.description: 1H FY26 tested this thesis hard. Underlying NPATA fell 7% to US$1.9B, tracking below the full-year guidance of US$3.45-3.55B. Behring IG revenue declined 6% (volume growth offset by pricing pressure and destocking). Albumin dropped 27%, KCENTRA -20%. But the franchise quality indicators remain strong: Behring gross margins expanded to 51.7% (target 57% by FY28), Vifor grew 12%, cost savings are 60% achieved at half-year against the $100M FY26 target, and full-year guidance was reaffirmed — implying a significant 2H acceleration. At 13.4x forward P/E, the market is pricing permanent impairment that the numbers do not support.
requires: 2H FY26 NPATA acceleration to deliver full-year guidance of US$3.45-3.55B
Behring IG volume recovery in 2H as destocking ends; pricing stabilises
Cost savings program delivering remaining 40% of FY26 $100M target in 2H
Permanent CEO appointment within 6 months; strategic clarity restored
Albumin and KCENTRA declines proved seasonal/one-off, not structural
supporting: Financial Statements: Behring gross margin expanded to 51.7%; Vifor +12%; FCF US$2.93B (FY25); guidance reaffirmed
Broker Research: 13 Buy, 0 Sell; consensus target A$215-230 (30-40% upside from A$163)
Regulatory: FDA-approved HEMGENIX and ANDEMBRY providing new revenue; gene therapy pipeline maturing
Economic: IG demand still growing 7-10% annually; 1H weakness was destocking, not demand destruction
Academic: Plasma therapies structurally supply-constrained; no biosimilar competition pathway for IG
Competitor: Takeda underperforming; Grifols taken private; CSL competitive position strengthening
contradicting: 1H FY26 Results: Revenue -4%, NPATA -7%, Behring IG -6%, Albumin -27%, KCENTRA -20% — broad-based weakness
Leadership: CEO departed day before results; interim CEO has no direct biotherapeutics operating experience
Impairments: US$1.1B write-downs (mRNA $430M, Venofer $356M, PP&E $170M) signal prior capital allocation errors
Corporate Comms: Seqirus demerger abandoned; strategic direction uncertain under interim leadership

hypotheses.title: D2: Execution Risk in Transformation
hypotheses.description: 1H FY26 confirmed this thesis. The CEO departed the day before results that revealed US$1.1B in impairments, broad-based revenue declines (Behring -7%, Albumin -27%, KCENTRA -20%), and a reported NPAT drop of 81%. The impairments signal prior capital allocation mistakes: $430M mRNA write-down (pandemic-era bet that failed), $356M Venofer write-down (generics competition), $170M plant closures. The interim CEO is a board director, not an operational executive. The cost savings program ($550M target by FY28) is on track but cannot mask the reality that this company is being restructured while simultaneously trying to maintain growth. Execution risk is no longer theoretical.
supporting: 1H FY26 Results: Revenue -4%, NPATA -7%, reported NPAT -81%; broad weakness across Behring product lines
Impairments: US$1.1B write-downs confirm past capital allocation errors (mRNA, Venofer, plant closures)
Leadership: CEO McKenzie departed 10 Feb 2026; interim CEO Gordon Naylor has no biotherapeutics operating experience
Corporate Comms: Seqirus demerger abandoned; no clarity on strategic direction under new leadership
Alt Data: 3,000 headcount reduction (8.5%) signals restructuring deeper than disclosed
Media: Negative press cycle; "governance questions" and "strategic confusion" framing dominant
contradicting: Guidance Reaffirmed: Full-year NPATA US$3.45-3.55B maintained, implying strong 2H acceleration
Behring Margins: Gross margin expanded to 51.7%; cost savings 60% achieved at half-year
Broker Research: 13 Buy, 0 Sell maintained through the results; analysts view dislocation as temporary

hypotheses.title: D3: Structural Headwinds Emerging
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↑ 1H confirmed headwinds in albumin, KCENTRA, Seqirus
hypotheses.description: 1H FY26 provided concrete evidence for multiple structural headwinds. Albumin revenue dropped 27% as Chinese domestic producers gain market share. KCENTRA fell 20% on increased competition and formulary pressure. Seqirus declined 2% as post-COVID flu vaccine demand continues normalising. The US$356M Venofer write-down confirms generic iron competition is eroding Vifor's legacy product economics. These are not one-off misses — each reflects structural shifts in competitive dynamics.
supporting: 1H FY26 Results: Albumin -27%, KCENTRA -20%, Seqirus -2% — three distinct product headwinds in one half
Impairments: $356M Venofer write-down confirms generic iron competition is permanently impairing returns
Competitor: Chinese albumin producers (CNBG, Shanghai RAAS) expanding capacity; import substitution accelerating
Economic: Flu vaccination rates declining to pre-COVID norms; Seqirus revenue base structurally lower
Academic: Subcutaneous IG delivery shifting competitive dynamics; biosimilar iron products gaining traction
contradicting: Vifor: Revenue grew 12% in 1H; nephrology franchise offsetting iron generics pressure
Gene Therapy: HEMGENIX and ANDEMBRY provide new addressable markets beyond legacy portfolio
IG Demand: Core immunoglobulin demand remains structurally supply-constrained; 1H IG weakness was destocking

hypotheses.title: D4: M&A or Corporate Event
hypotheses.statusText: Materialised — CEO Departure is the Corporate Event
hypotheses.scoreMeta: ↑ CEO exit + impairments + depressed valuation = event risk elevated
hypotheses.description: The corporate event has already begun. CEO departure, $1.1B impairments signalling portfolio clean-up, A$750M buyback expanded, and the stock at an 8-year low of 13.4x forward P/E (vs 5-year average ~35x). The clean-up suggests a new CEO will inherit a leaner balance sheet. A revived Seqirus demerger under new leadership is plausible. At A$73.2B market cap (down from A$130B), activist pressure or private equity interest in Vifor or Seqirus becomes more credible. Grifols taken private by Brookfield in 2024 set the plasma sector M&A precedent.
supporting: CEO Departure: McKenzie exit + $1.1B impairment clean-up = classic prelude to strategic reset under new leadership
Valuation: A$73.2B market cap at 13.4x fwd P/E; cheapest in 14 years; sum-of-parts compelling for activists
Buyback: A$750M expanded buyback signals board conviction stock is undervalued
Competitor: Grifols taken private by Brookfield in 2024; plasma sector M&A precedent established
contradicting: A$73.2B market cap still makes full acquisition very expensive; more likely partial disposals
Seqirus demerger already attempted and abandoned; board credibility cost of re-announcing
Regulatory complexity across US, EU, and Australia deters hostile approaches

narrative.theNarrative: The market narrative has shifted from "transformation risk" to "is this franchise permanently impaired?" The 1H FY26 results answered the transformation question — it is messy but manageable — and raised a new one about franchise quality. Revenue fell 4%, underlying NPATA dropped 7%, Behring IG declined 6%, albumin collapsed 27%, and KCENTRA fell 20%. The CEO departed the day before announcing US$1.1B in impairments. The stock crashed 17% intraday to A$151, an 8-year low, before recovering to ~A$163. At 13.4x forward P/E, the cheapest valuation in 14 years, the market is pricing permanent impairment of the franchise. The evidence says otherwise: Behring margins expanded, Vifor grew 12%, guidance was reaffirmed, and global IG demand remains structurally supply-constrained. This is a messy transition, not a broken franchise — but the market is demanding proof, not promises.

priceImplication.label: Embedded Assumptions at A$151.56
priceImplication.content: 1H weakness persists into 2H: Market doubts the implied 2H NPATA acceleration needed to hit full-year guidance. Impairments signal more to come: $1.1B write-down raises question of further portfolio clean-up under new CEO. Leadership vacuum: Interim CEO with no biotech operating experience; permanent appointment uncertain. Structural product decline: Albumin -27% and KCENTRA -20% treated as structural, not cyclical. Cost savings insufficient: $550M program cannot offset revenue declines if Behring growth does not recover.

narrative.evidenceCheck: 1H FY26 results have clarified the evidence picture significantly. The bear case gained evidence: revenue declined, NPATA fell, impairments were large, the CEO departed abruptly, and multiple product lines weakened simultaneously. The bull case held its ground: Behring gross margins expanded to 51.7%, Vifor grew 12%, cost savings are 60% delivered at half-year, full-year guidance was reaffirmed, and the stock trades at 13.4x forward P/E — a valuation that has historically marked generational buying opportunities in quality healthcare franchises. The question is no longer whether CSL faces challenges (it does) but whether the price already more than discounts those challenges. At current levels, the evidence suggests it does.
narrative.narrativeStability: Event-dependent and volatile. The 1H results triggered a 17% crash followed by partial recovery — the narrative is being actively contested. A strong 2H delivering on guidance would restore the "structural compounder" thesis rapidly. A permanent CEO appointment with clear strategic mandate would resolve governance overhang. Conversely, a 2H miss or further impairments would confirm the "permanently impaired" narrative. The next 6 months are unusually high-diagnosticity for a company that was historically one of the most stable on the ASX.

evidence.intro: Ten evidence domains assessed. Evidence ranked: Facts (filed, audited) > Company Releases (motivated but primary) > Broker Research (fact + opinion blend) > Social & Media (noise, contextual only).

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding: CEO Paul McKenzie departed 10 February 2026, the day before 1H FY26 results. Interim CEO Gordon Naylor (board director, former Orica CFO) presented results showing: revenue US$8.3B (-4%), underlying NPATA US$1.9B (-7%), reported NPAT US$401M (-81%) after US$1.1B in impairments. Full-year guidance of NPATA US$3.45-3.55B was reaffirmed, implying significant 2H acceleration. Cost savings program described as "on track" with 60% of FY26 $100M target achieved at half. A$750M buyback expanded. Dividend maintained at US$1.30. Seqirus demerger remains abandoned with no update on strategic direction.
cards.tension: The CEO departure timing and the scale of impairments together create a governance narrative that overshadows the underlying business quality. McKenzie departed citing "personal reasons" but the $1.1B impairment clean-up — writing down his own decisions on mRNA and Venofer — raises obvious questions about whether the exit was truly voluntary. The reaffirmed guidance is credible (Behring 2H seasonality is real) but requires trust in a leadership team that just changed. The market's 17% sell-off suggests trust is in short supply.
cards.source: CSL 1H FY26 Results, 12 Feb 2026; CEO departure ASX announcement; interim CEO appointment; results presentation

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding: 1H FY26 results (12 Feb 2026): Revenue US$8.3B (-4% CC). Underlying NPATA US$1.9B (-7%). Reported NPAT US$401M (-81%) after US$1.1B impairments. Behring: IG -6% to US$3.05B, Albumin -27%, KCENTRA -20%, gross margin expanded to 51.7%. Vifor: Revenue +12%. Seqirus: Revenue -2%. Impairment detail: mRNA write-down US$430M, Venofer generic competition US$356M, PP&E closures US$170M. Dividend US$1.30 (unchanged). FY25 audited: Revenue US$15B (+5%), FCF US$2.93B (+53%), EBITDA margin 32.7%. Debt/equity 0.54x. No audit qualifications.
cards.tension: 1H results present two realities simultaneously. The reported numbers are alarming: NPAT -81%, $1.1B impairments, revenue declining. But the underlying franchise indicators are defensible: Behring margins expanding, Vifor growing, cost savings on track, guidance maintained. The impairments are entirely backward-looking (mRNA failure, Venofer generics, plant rationalisation) and do not impair the core plasma franchise. The critical question is whether 2H can deliver the acceleration implied by full-year guidance.

tags.text: Mixed on T1 (underlying okay, headline weak)
Supports T3 (albumin, KCENTRA, Seqirus all weak)

cards.source: CSL 1H FY26 Results, 12 Feb 2026; CSL FY25 Annual Report; audited financial statements

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding: Overwhelmingly bullish. 13 Buy, 0 Sell. Median 12-month target A$230-237, implying 28-31% upside from current price. UBS, Macquarie, and Morgan Stanley all maintain Overweight/Buy through the CEO transition, viewing the leadership change as temporary noise rather than structural impairment. Consensus NPATA for FY26 is US$3.45-3.55B, in line with guidance. Analysts highlight that CSL's current P/E of 16.8x represents the most attractive entry point in over a decade for a business with this quality of cash flow generation.
cards.tension: The uniformity of Buy ratings amid a CEO departure is notable. Either analysts are right that the franchise transcends any single leader (CSL has navigated multiple CEO transitions before), or the sell-side is slow to reprice governance risk. The gap between price and target suggests the market is pricing risk that consensus does not.
cards.source: UBS, Macquarie, Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, Citi consensus data; TipRanks; MarketScreener

cards.title: 4. Competitor Disclosures
cards.finding: Takeda: Plasma-derived therapies division underperforming; reported manufacturing quality issues at US facilities. Market share in IG products declining. Grifols: Taken private by Brookfield in 2024 following years of governance scandals and debt concerns; effectively removed as a listed competitor. Chinese fractionators: Expanding albumin production capacity domestically, reducing reliance on imports. CNBG (China National Biotec Group) and Shanghai RAAS increasing plasma collection volumes. BioLife/Kedrion: Smaller players without CSL's scale or product breadth.
cards.tension: CSL's competitive position in plasma is strengthening as Takeda struggles and Grifols exits public markets. However, the China albumin market is genuinely shifting toward domestic supply, which could reduce CSL's growth in Asia. The competitive landscape supports the core franchise thesis but highlights geographic risk.
cards.source: Takeda FY25 results; Grifols/Brookfield deal disclosures; Chinese NMPA filings; industry data

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding: Global immunoglobulin demand growing at 7-10% annually, driven by ageing demographics, expanded diagnostic criteria for autoimmune diseases, and increasing use of subcutaneous IG in home settings. Plasma collection volumes have normalised post-COVID after significant disruption in 2020-2022. US donor economics stable with modest fee increases. Influenza vaccination rates declining toward pre-COVID baselines, creating headwinds for Seqirus. Iron deficiency and nephrology markets (Vifor) growing mid-single digits on expanded screening protocols.
cards.source: WHO immunisation data; MRB plasma industry reports; US CDC vaccination data; nephrology market studies

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding: Workforce reduction: Headcount fell from 32,698 to 29,904 (down 8.5%), representing approximately 3,000 job cuts. This is the largest workforce reduction in CSL's history and was not prominently disclosed in corporate communications. Plasma collection centre activity: US collection volumes appear stable based on donor traffic data, supporting the Behring revenue thesis. Gene therapy signals: HEMGENIX pricing at US$3.5M per treatment generating mixed uptake data; some treatment centres reporting slower-than-expected adoption due to payer pushback on gene therapy pricing.
cards.tension: The 3,000-job cut is significant and underreported. While framed as efficiency improvement, the scale suggests deeper cost pressures than management has publicly acknowledged. This is the strongest data point supporting T2 (execution risk in transformation).
cards.source: LinkedIn workforce data; US plasma centre traffic analytics; gene therapy adoption surveys; CSL Annual Report headcount disclosures

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding: Published research on plasma-derived therapies confirms that immunoglobulin demand is structurally supply-constrained: global plasma collection capacity cannot scale fast enough to meet growing demand for neurological and autoimmune indications. Subcutaneous IG delivery is expanding the addressable market by enabling home treatment. Gene therapy research indicates HEMGENIX-class treatments will supplement, not replace, IG therapy for at least 15-20 years due to limited patient eligibility and payer resistance. Academic studies on CEO succession in large-cap healthcare companies show median share price recovery within 6-12 months absent fundamental deterioration.
cards.source: The Lancet Neurology; Blood journal; Journal of Clinical Immunology; CEO succession studies in healthcare

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding: Negative sentiment dominated by CEO departure timing. Financial press framing: "governance questions," "strategic confusion," and "leadership vacuum." The Seqirus demerger reversal received significant negative coverage. Social sentiment on investment forums is bearish, focused on the share price decline from A$290 highs and the unusual timing of McKenzie's departure. Positive coverage limited to value investors highlighting the decade-low P/E. No credible reporting suggests operational deterioration in the core plasma business.
cards.source: Australian Financial Review; Reuters; Bloomberg; investment forums; financial press

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding: Leadership transition at a critical juncture. CEO Paul McKenzie departed 10 February 2026 after leading CSL through the US$11.7B Vifor acquisition and initiating the $550M cost restructuring. His exit, the day before 1H FY26 results, is the single most unusual governance event in CSL's modern history. Interim CEO Gordon Naylor is a board director and former Orica CFO with no direct biotherapeutics operating experience. The board, chaired by Paul Perreault (former CSL CEO 2013-2020), has deep plasma industry knowledge. Key question: whether Perreault's return as Chairman signals a brief transition to a prepared successor or a longer search that creates strategic drift.

rows: CSL CEO 7 years; US plasma industry veteran

cards.source: CSL Annual Report FY25; ASX announcements; board biographical disclosures; CEO departure notice

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding: Institutional register with growing value-investor interest. CSL's register has historically been dominated by growth-oriented institutional holders. The 40% price decline has triggered register rotation: growth managers reducing positions while value-oriented and income-focused funds begin accumulating. The A$750M buyback provides price support and signals management conviction. Short interest is low (~1-1.5%), indicating bears are not aggressively positioned despite the price decline. Insider transactions are limited to routine performance rights; no discretionary director purchases at current prices, though the CEO departure complicates insider trading windows.
cards.source: ASX substantial holder notices; ASIC short position reports; CSL Annual Report top-20 register

discriminators.intro: Four data points carry high diagnosticity. 1H FY26 results have resolved one discriminator and sharpened the remaining three.

rows.evidence: 1H FY26 Results (12 Feb 2026) — RESOLVED. Behring IG -6%, NPATA -7%, $1.1B impairments, CEO departed. Result was mixed: franchise intact but execution messy.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (franchise intact) vs T2 (transformation disrupting operations)
rows.currentReading: T2 confirmed; T1 weakened but not invalidated

rows.evidence: Permanent CEO appointment timeline and identity. Internal promotion signals continuity; external hire signals strategic reset.
rows.currentReading: Search underway — no timeline; interim CEO presenting

rows.evidence: 2H FY26 NPATA acceleration. Guidance implies US$1.55-1.65B in 2H (vs US$1.9B in 1H). Must deliver to validate reaffirmed guidance.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (guidance credible, 2H seasonal strength) vs T2 (guidance cut risk, cost pressures)

rows.evidence: Albumin trend in 2H. 1H albumin -27% was the largest single product decline. If structural (China substitution), T3 strengthens materially.
rows.discriminatesBetween: T1 (one-off destocking) vs T3 (permanent China import substitution)

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: "Share price down 40%" (price decline is the question, not the answer) • "P/E of 13.4x looks cheap" (cheap can get cheaper if 2H misses) • "US$1.1B impairments" (backward-looking; does not impair core franchise) • "Consensus Buy" (uniformity may reflect slow re-rating rather than conviction)

tripwires.intro: Four revision conditions. The first tripwire has been triggered — 1H results came in mixed, confirming T2 but not invalidating T1. The remaining three are now more diagnostic than ever.

cards.name: 1H FY26 Results — TRIGGERED

conditions.if: NPATA US$1.9B (-7%); Behring IG -6%; Albumin -27%; KCENTRA -20%
conditions.then: Outcome: T2 confirmed (execution challenges real). T1 weakened but not invalidated (margins expanding, guidance reaffirmed). T3 gained evidence (albumin, KCENTRA structural declines).

conditions.if: US$1.1B impairments; CEO departed day before; stock crashed 17% to A$151
conditions.then: Outcome: T4 activated (corporate event materialised). Market priced worst case; partial recovery to A$163 suggests floor forming.

cards.source: Source: CSL 1H FY26 Results, 12 Feb 2026; ASX announcement

conditions.if: If appointment made within 6 months with clear strategic mandate
conditions.then: T2 weakens. Transition was orderly, not dysfunctional. Market re-rates.

conditions.if: If search extends beyond 6 months or interim CEO role becomes permanent
conditions.then: T2 strengthens. Prolonged uncertainty; Seqirus/Vifor strategic direction unresolved.

cards.name: FY26 Full Year Results — 2H Acceleration Test

conditions.if: If FY26 NPATA hits US$3.45-3.55B guidance and albumin stabilises
conditions.then: T1 strengthens decisively. 2H delivered. 1H was the trough. Market re-rates.

conditions.if: If NPATA misses guidance or further impairments emerge
conditions.then: T2 deepens. Guidance was not credible. Multiple compression continues toward A$140.

cards.source: Source: CSL FY26 Annual Report; segmental disclosures

cards.name: Seqirus Strategic Direction Under New CEO

conditions.if: If new CEO revives Seqirus demerger or announces Vifor/Seqirus sale
conditions.then: T4 crystallises. Sum-of-parts value unlocking; clean portfolio story.

conditions.if: If Seqirus remains integrated with no strategic clarity under new CEO
conditions.then: T2 persists. Conglomerate discount continues; capital allocation questions unresolved.

cards.source: Source: ASX announcements; new CEO strategic presentation

couldntAssess: CEO departure rationale: "Personal reasons" provides no analytical clarity. Whether this was genuinely personal, board-driven, or performance-related is the single most important unknown and cannot be assessed from public data.
Seqirus standalone economics: CSL does not disclose Seqirus stand-alone profitability in sufficient detail to value a demerger. Without this, sum-of-parts analysis relies on estimates.

Gene therapy payer dynamics: HEMGENIX at US$3.5M per treatment faces payer pushback that is difficult to quantify. Uptake trajectories depend on reimbursement negotiations that are not publicly disclosed.
China regulatory trajectory: The pace of Chinese import substitution in albumin depends on NMPA regulatory decisions that are opaque to external analysts.
gaps.analyticalLimitations: Hypothesis survival scores (T1: 45%, T2: 55%, T3: 40%, T4: 35%) reflect editorial assessment updated post-1H FY26 results. T2 (Execution Risk) is now the dominant hypothesis after 1H confirmed broad-based weakness, $1.1B impairments, and CEO departure. T1 (Structural Compounder) remains viable but weakened — the franchise indicators are defensible but headline numbers were poor. T3 gained evidence from albumin -27%, KCENTRA -20%, and Seqirus -2%. T4 elevated by the CEO departure and portfolio clean-up. These scores will be revised materially based on 2H FY26 results and permanent CEO appointment.

crossover.description: 50-day MA crossed below 200-day MA following sharp selloff; gap widening

trend.structure: Consolidation base broken by 1H FY26 results crash; new 8-year low at A$151

support.method: Intraday 1H results crash low (12 Feb 2026); 8-year low

resistance.method: Prior support turned resistance; former consolidation base

priorSpikes.context: Sharp selloff from A$271 to A$225
1H FY26 results + CEO departure; crashed 17% intraday to A$151

inflectionPoints.event: Sharp selloff; drops 17% in one week
Death cross forms; 50-day MA below 200-day MA
1H results + CEO exit; crashed 17% intraday to 8-year low; recovered to A$163

footer.disclaimer: This report does not constitute personal financial advice. Continuum Intelligence synthesises cross-domain evidence using the Analysis of Competing Hypotheses (ACH) methodology. All factual claims are sourced from ASX filings, ACCC publications, broker consensus data, and publicly available information. This report does not contain buy, sell, or hold recommendations, price targets, or valuation models.
